elements.content: Scaling down the size of metal–organic framework (MOF) particles is a challenging but important task for extending the spectrum of potential MOF applications. Herein, we describe downsizing particles of MFU-4, a benzobistriazolate-based Zn­(II)-MOF, which can be prepared by either solvothermal or microwave-assisted synthesis. We report on combining various synthetic strategies leading to a production of nanosized MOF crystals of well-defined sizes and shape. Our approaches include varying reaction time, temperature, solvent choice, and amount of additives (alkali hydroxides or selected amines) in order to gain control over the nucleation process. As a result, the crystal sizes can be tuned over a broad range, from 40 nm large globular particles up to 5 μm cubic crystals with narrow size distributions. Additionally, the article offers a comparison of different techniques used to determine the particle size of crystals. These include dynamic light scattering, X-ray powder diffraction (from Scherrer equation), and transmission electron microscopy.

As a result, the crystal sizes can be tuned over a broad range, from 40 nm large globular particles up to 5 μm cubic crystals with narrow size distributions. elements.content: Size-controlled metal−organic framework (MOF) nanocrystals: We report an extensive study on size-controlled crystal growth of benzobistriazole-based Zn­(II)-MOF (MFU-4). Influence of synthesis method, temperature, time, solvent, and additives on crystal size and morphology is studied. Comparison of different methods for evaluating crystal sizes (including dynamic light scattering, X-ray powder diffraction, and transmission electron microscopy) is shown. Reported findings may be transferable to other MOFs including imidazole- and pyrazolate-based MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Size-controlled metal-organic framework (MOF) nanocrystals: We report an extensive study on size-controlled crystal growth of benzobistriazole-based Zn(II)-MOF (MFU-4). Influence of synthesis method, temperature, time, solvent, and additives on crystal size and morphology is studied. Comparison of different methods for evaluating crystal sizes (including dynamic light scattering, X-ray powder diffraction, and transmission electron microscopy) is shown. Reported findings may be transferable to other MOFs including imidazole- and pyrazolate-based MOFs.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous materials consisting of metal ions and polydentate bridging organic ligands. In contrast to other common porous materials, such as zeolites and carbon-based materials, the pore size, and pore and surface polarity of MOFs can be adjusted by a suitable choice of ligands and/or metal ions, which they are formed from. MOFs, as exceptionally highly porous systems, have already found applications as functional host materials in gas storage, adsorption, separation, and catalysis. To extend the spectrum of their applications to other fields including biology, drug delivery, and biomedical imaging, a precise control over the particle size and morphology is needed, because only sufficiently small particles (<100 nm) are able to penetrate into cells.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are porous materials consisting of metal ions and polydentate bridging organic ligands. In contrast to other common porous materials, such as zeolites and carbon-based materials, the pore size, and pore and surface polarity of MOFs can be adjusted by a suitable choice of ligands and/or metal ions, which they are formed from. MOFs, as exceptionally highly porous systems, have already found applications as functional host materials in gas storage, adsorption, separation, and catalysis. To extend the spectrum of their applications to other fields including biology, drug delivery, and biomedical imaging, a precise control over the particle size and morphology is needed, because only sufficiently small particles (<100 nm) are able to penetrate into cells.

elements.content: Recently, scaling down MOF materials has provided an exciting new class of materials known as nanoscale MOFs (NMOFs). These offer the same rich diversity of compositions, structures, and properties of bulk MOFs with the advantages of nanomaterials. For nanomaterials, not only their chemical composition but also their morphological properties such as size, shape, and surface properties determine their characteristics. These parameters can affect the chemical properties, reactivity, (photo-) catalytic activities of a substance as well as energetic properties and their confinement. The properties of materials change as their size approaches the nanoscale and as the percentage of atoms at the surface of a material becomes significant. There has been an increasing interest in developing new synthesis routes to produce MOF nanoparticles, even if examples of NMOFs are still quite rare. The size of MOF crystals usually depends on the chosen method of their preparation. However, temperature and heating rates during the MOF synthesis provide additional parameters to control the nucleation process and crystal growth. Various methods for NMOFs synthesis have been reported. These include sonochemical and microwave-assisted syntheses, microemulsion synthesis, surfactant-assisted synthesis, and coordination modulation. However, whatever the method used and the targeted solid, there is still a lack of knowledge concerning the key parameters required for the control of the MOF particle growth and scaling down its size to less than 100 nm. This is why we have initiated an extended study dealing with two different synthesis methods and various synthesis conditions in order to develop synthesis routes to NMOFs (>100 nm) with narrow size distributions.

elements.content: Herein, we report a comparative study on the synthesis of MFU-4 (1, MFU being an acronym for Metal-organic Framework Ulm University). However, we believe that our approaches are transferable to many other N-donor ligand based MOFs as well. MFU-4 is an example of a benzenetriazolate-based MOF and belongs to the “MFU-4-type” frameworks recently reported by our group. The modular MFU-4 family is based on Kuratowski-type pentanuclear secondary building units (SBUs) of the general formula [MII 5X4(L6)] (). In the pentanuclear coordination unit, the central metal­(II) ion is in an octahedral geometry, coordinated to six triazolate ligands. The other four peripheral metal­(II) ions feature a tetrahedral coordination environment, and each of them is bound to three N-donor atoms stemming from different benzotriazolate ligands and to one additional monodentate (anionic) ligand, e.g., a halide anion (here chloride). Benzotriazolate-based MOFs were shown to be capable of molecular sieving, band gap engineering, and activation of small molecules. To the best of our knowledge, there have been no examples of nanosized MOFs based on triazolate ligands reported so far. In this work, two different synthetic methods, solvothermal and MW-assisted synthesis, were used to prepare MFU-4 nanocrystals. The particle size, size distribution, and the reaction yield have been determined as a function of various parameters such as reaction temperature, time, and nature of the solvent. As an attempt to better control crystal growth by controlled deprotonation of the ligands, the addition of a base (sodium and potassium hydroxide or various amines) was investigated too.

elements.content: All reagents were of reagent grade and used as received from commercial suppliers. The organic ligand {1H,5H-benzo­(1,2-d:4,5-d′)­bistriazole, H2-BBTA} was synthesized in six steps starting from commercially available 1,3-dichlorobenzene following the procedures published in the literature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Chemicals and Synthesis

All reagents were of reagent grade and used as received from commercial suppliers. The organic ligand {1H,5H-benzo(1,2-d:4,5-d')bistriazole, H2-BBTA} was synthesized in six steps starting from commercially available 1,3-dichlorobenzene following the procedures published in the literature.

elements.content: A typical solvothermal synthesis was performed as follows: a solution of anhydrous zinc chloride (34 mg, 0.25 mmol) and 1H,5H-benzo­(1,2-d:4,5-d′)­bistriazole (H2-BBTA, 10 mg, 0.06 mmol) in 2 mL of DMF was prepared in a heating test tube and placed into a heating block at 40, 60, 70, 90, 110, and 140 °C for 24 h. The obtained precipitate was examined with an optical microscope and then recovered by centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 10 min. The obtained solid was washed three times with DMF and dried in air. The reaction yield was calculated. All reactions were performed thrice to calculate the average and standard deviation.
elements.clean_text:
Solvothermal Synthesis of MFU-4

A typical solvothermal synthesis was performed as follows: a solution of anhydrous zinc chloride (34 mg, 0.25 mmol) and 1H,5H-benzo(1,2-d:4,5-d')bistriazole (H2-BBTA, 10 mg, 0.06 mmol) in 2 mL of DMF was prepared in a heating test tube and placed into a heating block at 40, 60, 70, 90, 110, and 140 °C for 24 h. The obtained precipitate was examined with an optical microscope and then recovered by centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 10 min. The obtained solid was washed three times with DMF and dried in air. The reaction yield was calculated. All reactions were performed thrice to calculate the average and standard deviation.

elements.content: A typical microwave-assisted synthesis was performed as follows: a solution of anhydrous zinc chloride (34 mg, 0.25 mmol) and 1H,5H-benzo­(1,2-d:4,5-d′)­bistriazole (H2-BBTA, 10 mg, 0.06 mmol) in 2 mL of solvent (DMF, DMF–ethanol (1:1), ethanol, DMSO or water) in the presence or not of a selected base (2 mol equiv of potassium hydroxide, sodium hydroxide, trimethylamine, diethylamine, or n-hexylamine) was prepared in a Pyrex sample tube and placed in a microwave synthesizer (CEM, Discover S). The resulting mixture was heated in a pulsed mode (ΔT = 3 °C) at different temperatures (60, 80, 100, and 155 °C) at 100–300W for different times (2, 5, or 10 min). The obtained precipitate was recovered by centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 10 min, washed once with DMF and twice with ethanol, and dried in air. The efficiency of the MW-assisted synthesis was evaluated in terms of temperature, time, solvent, and presence of additives. Under these conditions, both particle size and reaction yields have been determined. All reactions were performed thrice to calculate the average and standard deviation.
elements.clean_text:
Microwave-Assisted Synthesis of MFU-4

A typical microwave-assisted synthesis was performed as follows: a solution of anhydrous zinc chloride (34 mg, 0.25 mmol) and 1H,5H-benzo(1,2-d:4,5-d')bistriazole (H2-BBTA, 10 mg, 0.06 mmol) in 2 mL of solvent (DMF, DMF-ethanol (1:1), ethanol, DMSO or water) in the presence or not of a selected base (2 mol equiv of potassium hydroxide, sodium hydroxide, trimethylamine, diethylamine, or n-hexylamine) was prepared in a Pyrex sample tube and placed in a microwave synthesizer (CEM, Discover S). The resulting mixture was heated in a pulsed mode (ΔT = 3 °C) at different temperatures (60, 80, 100, and 155 °C) at 100-300W for different times (2, 5, or 10 min). The obtained precipitate was recovered by centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 10 min, washed once with DMF and twice with ethanol, and dried in air. The efficiency of the MW-assisted synthesis was evaluated in terms of temperature, time, solvent, and presence of additives. Under these conditions, both particle size and reaction yields have been determined. All reactions were performed thrice to calculate the average and standard deviation.

elements.content: As-synthesized MFU-4 samples were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD), optical or transmission electron microscopy (TEM), dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and krypton sorption measurements. Photos of microcrystalline materials were taken using an Olympus IX70 microscope equipped with a CCD camera. TEM micrographs were taken using a JEOL 2100F microscope with a FEG electron source operated at 200 kV. Samples were prepared by depositing a drop of the dispersion of the crystalline products in ethanol onto carbon-coated copper grids (200 mesh) and dried in air. The size and size distribution of nanocrystals were measured using calibrated TEM images by ImageJ software. For each sample, 100 particles were measured to determine the average particle sizes from TEM micrographs. DLS measurements were performed on a Brookhaven 90Plus nanoparticle size analyzer. The hydrodynamic radius of the particles was determined by dynamic light scattering in diluted suspensions in DMF. The data are presented as a median for number distributions (Dn50) with a polydispersity index (PDI). Krypton (99.999%, Linde AG) sorption measurements in the BET range (p/p 0 = 0.01–0.4) were performed with a Quantachrome Autosorb-1c instrument at 77 K. Prior to measurements, samples were heated at 100–200 °C for 20 h in high vacuum in order to remove occluded solvent molecules. The BET surface areas, determined from the Kr sorption isotherms are given in m2 g–1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with a TGA Q500 analyzer in the temperature range of 25–800 °C in flowing nitrogen at a heating rate of 5 K min–1. X-ray powder diffraction data were collected using a Seifert XRD 3003 TT powder diffractometer with a Meteor1D detector operating from 5 to 50° 2θ using a step size of 0.02° and 4 s per step in continuous mode at room temperature using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54187 Å). The instrumental peak broadening needed for analyzing the diffraction peaks according to the Scherrer equation was determined using a silicon reference standard. Four most intensive diffraction peaks (centered at. 8.2, 11.7, 13.7, and 18.0° in 2θ) were used to calculate the average size of crystallites. The structure of compound 2 was determined from X-ray single crystal diffraction data. The single crystal of 2 was obtained by solvothermal synthesis at 60 °C for 1 day. The X-ray data for the single crystal structure determination of 2 were collected on a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer (see Supporting Information for the measurement details). Complete crystallographic data for the structure 2 reported in this paper have been deposited in the CIF format with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK as supplementary publication no. CCDC 1440258.
elements.clean_text:
Methods and Characterization

As-synthesized MFU-4 samples were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD), optical or transmission electron microscopy (TEM), dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and krypton sorption measurements. Photos of microcrystalline materials were taken using an Olympus IX70 microscope equipped with a CCD camera. TEM micrographs were taken using a JEOL 2100F microscope with a FEG electron source operated at 200 kV. Samples were prepared by depositing a drop of the dispersion of the crystalline products in ethanol onto carbon-coated copper grids (200 mesh) and dried in air. The size and size distribution of nanocrystals were measured using calibrated TEM images by ImageJ software. For each sample, 100 particles were measured to determine the average particle sizes from TEM micrographs. DLS measurements were performed on a Brookhaven 90Plus nanoparticle size analyzer. The hydrodynamic radius of the particles was determined by dynamic light scattering in diluted suspensions in DMF. The data are presented as a median for number distributions (Dn50) with a polydispersity index (PDI). Krypton (99.999%, Linde AG) sorption measurements in the BET range (p/p 0 = 0.01-0.4) were performed with a Quantachrome Autosorb-1c instrument at 77 K. Prior to measurements, samples were heated at 100-200 °C for 20 h in high vacuum in order to remove occluded solvent molecules. The BET surface areas, determined from the Kr sorption isotherms are given in m2 g-1. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with a TGA Q500 analyzer in the temperature range of 25-800 °C in flowing nitrogen at a heating rate of 5 K min-1. X-ray powder diffraction data were collected using a Seifert XRD 3003 TT powder diffractometer with a Meteor1D detector operating from 5 to 50° 2θ using a step size of 0.02° and 4 s per step in continuous mode at room temperature using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54187 Å). The instrumental peak broadening needed for analyzing the diffraction peaks according to the Scherrer equation was determined using a silicon reference standard. Four most intensive diffraction peaks (centered at. 8.2, 11.7, 13.7, and 18.0° in 2θ) were used to calculate the average size of crystallites. The structure of compound 2 was determined from X-ray single crystal diffraction data. The single crystal of 2 was obtained by solvothermal synthesis at 60 °C for 1 day. The X-ray data for the single crystal structure determination of 2 were collected on a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer (see Supporting Information for the measurement details). Complete crystallographic data for the structure 2 reported in this paper have been deposited in the CIF format with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB21EZ, UK as supplementary publication no. CCDC 1440258.

elements.content: Our approach to the size-controlled synthesis of nano- and microscale MFU-4 materials is an extension of the methods we have recently developed for the production of MFU-4. MFU-4 (1) was prepared by either microwave-assisted synthesis or conventional solvothermal synthesis starting from benzobistriazole and anhydrous zinc chloride in dimethylformamide (DMF) at 155 °C for 10 min and 140 °C for 3 days, respectively. Utilizing these methods, micron-sized cubic crystals ranging from 2 to 10 μm in each dimension were obtained. The common approaches to prepare crystals of smaller sizes include lowering the reaction temperature and/or shortening the reaction time. Additionally to that, we investigated the use of different solvents and various additives on the crystal sizes too. The phase purity of obtained solids was proven by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) by comparing the XRD patterns with a reference material prepared by the reported procedures. In all herein reported experiments crystalline materials of MFU-4 were obtained (see diffractograms in Supporting Information, Figures S2 and S4–S7), except for the experiment resulting in the preparation of coordination polymer 2. Particle sizes were determined from the powder samples by XRD (Scherrer equation) and by DLS, thus providing information on both the size of the crystalline domains (XRD) and the primary particles (DLS – hydrodynamic diameter). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to confirm the crystal size and to check the crystal morphology. The different synthesis approaches were also evaluated in the terms of reaction yield, which is important considering a scaling-up production.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Our approach to the size-controlled synthesis of nano- and microscale MFU-4 materials is an extension of the methods we have recently developed for the production of MFU-4. MFU-4 (1) was prepared by either microwave-assisted synthesis or conventional solvothermal synthesis starting from benzobistriazole and anhydrous zinc chloride in dimethylformamide (DMF) at 155 °C for 10 min and 140 °C for 3 days, respectively. Utilizing these methods, micron-sized cubic crystals ranging from 2 to 10 μm in each dimension were obtained. The common approaches to prepare crystals of smaller sizes include lowering the reaction temperature and/or shortening the reaction time. Additionally to that, we investigated the use of different solvents and various additives on the crystal sizes too. The phase purity of obtained solids was proven by X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) by comparing the XRD patterns with a reference material prepared by the reported procedures. In all herein reported experiments crystalline materials of MFU-4 were obtained (see diffractograms in Supporting Information, Figures S2 and S4-S7), except for the experiment resulting in the preparation of coordination polymer 2. Particle sizes were determined from the powder samples by XRD (Scherrer equation) and by DLS, thus providing information on both the size of the crystalline domains (XRD) and the primary particles (DLS - hydrodynamic diameter). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to confirm the crystal size and to check the crystal morphology. The different synthesis approaches were also evaluated in the terms of reaction yield, which is important considering a scaling-up production.

elements.content: It is known that decreasing temperature often leads to smaller crystals sizes as a consequence of reduced crystal growth rate. Unfortunately, it often results in lowering reaction yields, too. This assumption was confirmed also in our case. The results of solvothermal synthesis of MFU-4 revealed decreasing reaction yield upon lowering the reaction temperature; compare a yield of 72.5 ± 3.4% obtained at 140 °C for 1 day, and a yield of 54.5 ± 3.8% obtained at 110 °C for the same period. However, the decrease in the crystal size was not very significant, and no nanosized crystals could be obtained (see and Figure S1 in Supporting Information). Interestingly, at lower reaction temperatures the formation of another crystalline phase was observed (). This phase was characterized as a two-dimensional coordination polymer (2, for details on crystallographic data see Supporting Information). In the structure of 2, only four of the six nitrogen atoms of the benzobistriazolate linker are coordinated to the zinc ions. In order to prepare phase pure MFU-4 at a temperature lower than 80 °C, addition of an auxiliary base was needed, because the low reaction temperature seems to prevent the formation of dimethylamine base from hydrolytic decomposition of DMF. This is demonstrated by the successful preparation of MFU-4 (1) at 60 °C, in the presence of added 2,6-lutidine (2 equiv), serving as auxiliary base with only weak potential to form coordinative bonds to the zinc centers.
elements.clean_text:
Role of Temperature

It is known that decreasing temperature often leads to smaller crystals sizes as a consequence of reduced crystal growth rate. Unfortunately, it often results in lowering reaction yields, too. This assumption was confirmed also in our case. The results of solvothermal synthesis of MFU-4 revealed decreasing reaction yield upon lowering the reaction temperature; compare a yield of 72.5 ± 3.4% obtained at 140 °C for 1 day, and a yield of 54.5 ± 3.8% obtained at 110 °C for the same period. However, the decrease in the crystal size was not very significant, and no nanosized crystals could be obtained (see  and Figure S1 in Supporting Information). Interestingly, at lower reaction temperatures the formation of another crystalline phase was observed (). This phase was characterized as a two-dimensional coordination polymer (2, for details on crystallographic data see Supporting Information). In the structure of 2, only four of the six nitrogen atoms of the benzobistriazolate linker are coordinated to the zinc ions. In order to prepare phase pure MFU-4 at a temperature lower than 80 °C, addition of an auxiliary base was needed, because the low reaction temperature seems to prevent the formation of dimethylamine base from hydrolytic decomposition of DMF. This is demonstrated by the successful preparation of MFU-4 (1) at 60 °C, in the presence of added 2,6-lutidine (2 equiv), serving as auxiliary base with only weak potential to form coordinative bonds to the zinc centers.

elements.clean_text: 1  Influence of Temperature on Coordination Polymer Formation

elements.content: In the case of microwave-assisted synthesis, the decrease in reaction temperature results in a preparation of smaller crystals (see and Figure S3 in Supporting Information). This decrease in size is more significant compared to the solvothermal synthesis, unfortunately, still on the cost of lowering the reaction yields compare a yield of 51.5 ± 6.4% obtained for reaction mixture held at 155 °C for 10 min, and a yield of 9.0 ± 3.2% for 100 °C and 10 min reaction time. The microwave radiation accelerates the nucleation and increases the seed number via hot spot formation, avoiding the fast growth of MOF crystals, which results in the production of a larger amount of smaller crystals. Additionally, it is a fast synthetic method (only several minutes are required) in direct comparison to solvothermal synthesis, which leads to phase pure MFU-4 (1), even when low temperatures are used. Therefore, this method was chosen as a preferred one and changes of additional parametersincluding solvent, time, and additiveswere further examined further in subsequent microwave syntheses protocols. The efficacy of MW-assisted synthesis has been evaluated in terms of the nature of the solvent, reaction time, and the variable amount of additives, while retaining a constant solvent volume of 2 mL and a 4:1 molar ratio of zinc chloride andbenzobistriazole, respecitively. Under these conditions, both particle size and reaction yield have been determined.
elements.clean_text: In the case of microwave-assisted synthesis, the decrease in reaction temperature results in a preparation of smaller crystals (see  and Figure S3 in Supporting Information). This decrease in size is more significant compared to the solvothermal synthesis, unfortunately, still on the cost of lowering the reaction yields compare a yield of 51.5 ± 6.4% obtained for reaction mixture held at 155 °C for 10 min, and a yield of 9.0 ± 3.2% for 100 °C and 10 min reaction time. As shown above (), the presence of base is crucial in order to prepare a phase pure MFU-4. When DMF is used as a solvent, at elevated temperatures (>70 °C) a base dimethylamine is generated in situ by the solvent decomposition. When other solvents such as DMSO, EtOH, water, and their mixtures are used, the formation of organic base equivalents is impossible, and therefore, no MFU-4 formation could be observed (neither by solvothermal synthesis nor by microwave synthesis). However, using mixtures of DMF with the selected solvents led to successful formation of MFU-4. For instance a mixture of DMF and ethanol in a 1:1 ratio was found to produce significantly better results with regard to decreasing crystal sizes and increasing reaction yields if compared to experiments in which pure DMF was used as solvent under the same reaction conditions (, Figure S3 in Supporting Information); compare a yield of 9.0 ± 3.2% obtained for a reaction at 100 °C for 10 min in DMF, and a yield of 63.2 ± 6.2% at the same conditions in a mixed solvent (DMF–EtOH, 1:1). This observation might be ascribed to the differences in dipolar moments (μ = 3.86 D for DMF and μ = 1.68 D for ethanol). A higher dipolar moment of the solvent typically changes both the solubility of the linker and the solvent–nanoparticle interface, changing the interfacial tension and thus strongly affecting the particle size. On the basis of the improved results of the MFU-4 synthesis when using DMF–ethanol (1:1), this solvent mixture was selected to be further used in the following studies to explore the remaining synthesis parameters (time and presence of additives).

Role of the Solvent

As shown above (), the presence of base is crucial in order to prepare a phase pure MFU-4. When DMF is used as a solvent, at elevated temperatures (>70 °C) a base dimethylamine is generated in situ by the solvent decomposition. When other solvents such as DMSO, EtOH, water, and their mixtures are used, the formation of organic base equivalents is impossible, and therefore, no MFU-4 formation could be observed (neither by solvothermal synthesis nor by microwave synthesis). However, using mixtures of DMF with the selected solvents led to successful formation of MFU-4. For instance a mixture of DMF and ethanol in a 1:1 ratio was found to produce significantly better results with regard to decreasing crystal sizes and increasing reaction yields if compared to experiments in which pure DMF was used as solvent under the same reaction conditions (, Figure S3 in Supporting Information); compare a yield of 9.0 ± 3.2% obtained for a reaction at 100 °C for 10 min in DMF, and a yield of 63.2 ± 6.2% at the same conditions in a mixed solvent (DMF-EtOH, 1:1). This observation might be ascribed to the differences in dipolar moments (μ = 3.86 D for DMF and μ = 1.68 D for ethanol). A higher dipolar moment of the solvent typically changes both the solubility of the linker and the solvent-nanoparticle interface, changing the interfacial tension and thus strongly affecting the particle size. On the basis of the improved results of the MFU-4 synthesis when using DMF-ethanol (1:1), this solvent mixture was selected to be further used in the following studies to explore the remaining synthesis parameters (time and presence of additives).

elements.content: In order to study the influence of time, the microwave-assisted synthesis was performed in a DMF–EtOH (1:1) solvent mixture at a fixed temperature of 100 °C at varying reaction time (10, 5, or 2 min). Upon shortening the reaction time from 10 to 2 min, the MFU-4 particles became smaller as shown by optical images (Figure S3 in Supporting Information). Unfortunately, the reaction yield also decreases from 63.2 ± 6.2% to 24.3 ± 5.1% (). This indicates that under the given reaction conditions the crystallization process is not completed, and simple metal complexes and free ligands remain in solution. Because of the decrease in reaction yields, shortening reaction time cannot be solitarily used for producing mass amounts of nanosized MFU-4 crystals. Therefore, combining reduced reaction time with approaches that lead to accelerated crystal nucleation rates must be considered, which includes using suitable additives.
elements.clean_text:
Role of Time

In order to study the influence of time, the microwave-assisted synthesis was performed in a DMF-EtOH (1:1) solvent mixture at a fixed temperature of 100 °C at varying reaction time (10, 5, or 2 min). Upon shortening the reaction time from 10 to 2 min, the MFU-4 particles became smaller as shown by optical images (Figure S3 in Supporting Information). Unfortunately, the reaction yield also decreases from 63.2 ± 6.2% to 24.3 ± 5.1% (). This indicates that under the given reaction conditions the crystallization process is not completed, and simple metal complexes and free ligands remain in solution. Because of the decrease in reaction yields, shortening reaction time cannot be solitarily used for producing mass amounts of nanosized MFU-4 crystals. Therefore, combining reduced reaction time with approaches that lead to accelerated crystal nucleation rates must be considered, which includes using suitable additives.

elements.content: The “ideal” synthesis of MOF nanoparticles requires a production of monodisperse crystals in high yields. This can be achieved by deliberate control over crystal nucleation and growth steps. Unfortunately, the discussed changes in reaction temperature, solvent, and/or time were not found to be sufficient. First, these changes do not lead to crystals small enough (<100 nm), and second, the changes leading to a decrease of crystal sizes result in the reactions with lower yields. Therefore, the addition of an auxiliary base was examined next. The presence of base is expected to result in a higher deprotonation rate of the linker molecules which should result in a higher nucleation rate leading to the smaller crystals but keeping high reaction yields. Two different reaction temperatures, 100 and 60 °C, were selected to study the influence of the base on the crystal size, polydispersity, and the yield of the reaction. Benzotriazoles are weak acids; for instance, the pK a value of benzotriazole is 8.2. Therefore, moderate bases can be used. To verify our assumption, a set of experiments utilizing common alkaline hydroxides serving as base was performed.
elements.clean_text:
Role of Additives

The "ideal" synthesis of MOF nanoparticles requires a production of monodisperse crystals in high yields. This can be achieved by deliberate control over crystal nucleation and growth steps. Unfortunately, the discussed changes in reaction temperature, solvent, and/or time were not found to be sufficient. First, these changes do not lead to crystals small enough (<100 nm), and second, the changes leading to a decrease of crystal sizes result in the reactions with lower yields. Therefore, the addition of an auxiliary base was examined next. The presence of base is expected to result in a higher deprotonation rate of the linker molecules which should result in a higher nucleation rate leading to the smaller crystals but keeping high reaction yields. Two different reaction temperatures, 100 and 60 °C, were selected to study the influence of the base on the crystal size, polydispersity, and the yield of the reaction. Benzotriazoles are weak acids; for instance, the pK a value of benzotriazole is 8.2. Therefore, moderate bases can be used. To verify our assumption, a set of experiments utilizing common alkaline hydroxides serving as base was performed.

elements.content: As expected when potassium hydroxide or sodium hydroxide (2 mol equiv for 1 mol equiv of the benzobistriazole ligand) was used as additives to the synthesis, particle sizes decreased significantly and nanocrystals of MFU-4 could be prepared. The added alkali base is responsible for the deprotonation of the organic ligands and thereby accelerates the framework formation (i.e., quicker linker deprotonation results in higher nucleation rates and consequently in a smaller final crystal sizes). No big differences were observed between the two different alkali hydroxides being used. TEM images of samples prepared at 60 °C revealed roughly spherical particles being <40 nm in size including some particles with sharp edges (). Not surprisingly, with an increase of temperature from 60 to 100 °C, slightly larger crystals were obtained, and the reaction yields increased too. Unfortunately, in all cases materials having relatively high polydispersity indexes (PDI: 0.288-0.405) were obtained. As can be seen from , the size values determined by XRD (Scherrer equation) and DLS are in good agreement for the products, confirming that the primary particles are crystalline MFU-4.

Naturally, using different amounts of base offers one further option how to tune the crystal sizes. A model study was carried out using potassium hydroxide as a base. As expected, a higher concentration of KOH leads to a higher degree of deprotonation of the ligand molecule (i.e., more deprotonated ligand molecules were available for coordination with metal ions) and, thus, a higher rate of nucleation and crystal growth, resulting in smaller MFU-4 nanocrystals. An average crystal size measured by DLS decreased significantly from ca. 1 μm when no base was used to ca. 40 nm when 2 equiv of KOH were added, whereas the reaction yield increases. This is a result of a higher degree of ligand deprotonation at higher concentrations of KOH ( and ). As indicated by TEM images (), the particles’ morphology obtained at high KOH concentration shows globular particles with average diameters of about 40 nm, while micron-sized cubic crystals were obtained without an addition of base.

Coordination modulation is another method which was previously reported in the literature to produce MOF nanoparticles. This method includes utilizing capping reagents (modulators), i.e., monodentate ligands with donor functionalities enabling coordinative interactions with the metal ions in the reaction mixture, and therefore to compete with the bridging (bifunctional) organic ligands. The modulation allows a control of the rate of framework extension and crystal growth. Adapting this approach, in our hands some control of crystal size was achieved by employing simple alkylamines (mono-, di-, or trisubstituted). These simple modulating ligands act not only as competitive ligands at the metal centers but also as bases and are responsible for the deprotonation of bridging ligands. Thus, they affect crystal nucleation and growth via both coordination and deprotonation equilibria.
elements.clean_text: Coordination modulation is another method which was previously reported in the literature to produce MOF nanoparticles. This method includes utilizing capping reagents (modulators), i.e., monodentate ligands with donor functionalities enabling coordinative interactions with the metal ions in the reaction mixture, and therefore to compete with the bridging (bifunctional) organic ligands. The modulation allows a control of the rate of framework extension and crystal growth. Adapting this approach, in our hands some control of crystal size was achieved by employing simple alkylamines (mono-, di-, or trisubstituted). These simple modulating ligands act not only as competitive ligands at the metal centers but also as bases and are responsible for the deprotonation of bridging ligands. Thus, they affect crystal nucleation and growth via both coordination and deprotonation equilibria.

elements.content: As an auxiliary ligand, we used triethylamine, diethylamine, and n-hexylamine. As expected, they were proven as effective modulators in reducing sizes of the MFU-4 crystals from micrometer (no additives) to nanometer sizes (with additives, and ). Diethylamine was found to work best as a modulator, since monodispersed crystals (PDI < 0.2 obtained at 100 and 60 °C) of well-defined cubic shape were prepared in very high yields (>90%). Interestingly, when n-hexylamine was used as an additive, the crystal morphology was dramatically influenced and instead of cubic crystals, octahedral crystals were obtained, while keeping the cubic crystal system (proven by indexing the XRPD patterns). Octahedral crystals can be obtained by slicing cubic crystals along the {111} crystal planes. On a molecular scale, the {111} cleavage surface exposes zinc ions at the interface to the solvent (). The addition of n-hexylamine to the reaction mixture strongly favors the formation of octahedral crystals, which implies that n-hexylamine stabilizes the {111} face terminated by zinc ions over the {100} face of the MFU-4 lattice. To gain more detail information about the influence of amines on the MFU-4 crystal growth, additional studies including different amines would be required.

Octahedral crystals can be obtained by slicing cubic crystals along the {111} crystal planes. On a molecular scale, the {111} cleavage surface exposes zinc ions at the interface to the solvent (). The addition of n-hexylamine to the reaction mixture strongly favors the formation of octahedral crystals, which implies that n-hexylamine stabilizes the {111} face terminated by zinc ions over the {100} face of the MFU-4 lattice. To gain more detail information about the influence of amines on the MFU-4 crystal growth, additional studies including different amines would be required.

elements.content: When MOF crystals are downsized to nanometer scales, the contribution of the crystal interface is no longer negligible. Simply in the cubic crystal morphology, the ratio of surface area over volume (S/V) can be denoted as S/V = 6/a, where a is the length of the side of cube. The high surface area gives nanoparticles unique properties in comparison to bulk material. For instance, nanoparticles can be easily suspended in solution, since the interaction of the particle surface with a solvent is strong enough to overcome density differences, which otherwise result in a material either sinking or floating in a liquid. The availability of nanoparticle suspensions is important for many applications including medicinal. To determine the external surface area of MFU-4 nanaocrystals, krypton was selected for gas sorption measurements. The large atomic diameter of krypton (van der Waals radius of 2.02 Å) prevents it from entering the internal void surface of the MFU-4 framework, which features ultranarrow pores of a limiting diameter of <4 Å.
elements.clean_text:
Sorption Properties and Thermal Stability of MFU-4 Crystals of Different Sizes

When MOF crystals are downsized to nanometer scales, the contribution of the crystal interface is no longer negligible. Simply in the cubic crystal morphology, the ratio of surface area over volume (S/V) can be denoted as S/V = 6/a, where a is the length of the side of cube. The high surface area gives nanoparticles unique properties in comparison to bulk material. For instance, nanoparticles can be easily suspended in solution, since the interaction of the particle surface with a solvent is strong enough to overcome density differences, which otherwise result in a material either sinking or floating in a liquid. The availability of nanoparticle suspensions is important for many applications including medicinal. To determine the external surface area of MFU-4 nanaocrystals, krypton was selected for gas sorption measurements. The large atomic diameter of krypton (van der Waals radius of 2.02 Å) prevents it from entering the internal void surface of the MFU-4 framework, which features ultranarrow pores of a limiting diameter of <4 Å.

The influence of crystal size on MOF thermal stability was investigated by thermogravimetric (TGA) measurements. The TGA results confirm that the nanosized MFU-4 crystals exhibit a good thermal stability similar to the reported bulk MFU-4 material. Two steps of weight loss were noted. The first step of weight loss from 150 to 300 °C is attributed to the physically adsorbed solvent molecules in the MFU-4 framework, and the second step from 400 to 500 °C is due to the framework decomposition. Nanocrystals (ca. 40 nm) decompose slowly starting at 400 °C, whereas larger nanocrystals and microcrystals begin to decompose at higher temperature (500 °C, ). This could be assigned to the fact that atoms situated at the surface of small nanoparticles have fewer neighbors than internal atoms, resulting in lower binding energy per atom with decreasing particle size. A consequence of reduced binding energy per atom is a lower temperature of framework decomposition.

This could be assigned to the fact that atoms situated at the surface of small nanoparticles have fewer neighbors than internal atoms, resulting in lower binding energy per atom with decreasing particle size. elements.content: We have reported on novel synthesis strategies to phase-pure MFU-4 nano- and microscale materials in which size-control between 40 nm to 5 μm was achieved. We showed that a decrease of reaction time or temperature leads to a reduction of MOF crystal sizes. Unfortunately, the reaction yield decreased too. However, the reaction yield could be improved by changing the polarity of the solvent. A DMF–EtOH (1:1) mixture was found to be a good solvent, leading to improved reaction yields (e.g., from 9.0 ± 3.2% in DMF at 100 °C for 10 min up to 63.2 ± 6.2% in DMF–EtOH at the same conditions). We showed that nucleation rate of MFU-4 could be greatly influenced by adding an alkali base which was responsible for ligand deprotonation. We also demonstrated that by changing the amount of added base, the crystal size could be finely tuned. Last but not least the usage of three simple amines (triethylamine, diethylamine, and n-hexylamine) as modulating ligands was studied. These act not only as competitive ligands in coordination equilibria but also as bases in deprotonation equilibria during nucleation and growth. Moreover, n-hexylamine was found to be a highly selective reagent, which changes the regular cubic crystal morphology of MFU-4 single crystals into an octahedral shape.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have reported on novel synthesis strategies to phase-pure MFU-4 nano- and microscale materials in which size-control between 40 nm to 5 μm was achieved. We showed that a decrease of reaction time or temperature leads to a reduction of MOF crystal sizes. Unfortunately, the reaction yield decreased too. However, the reaction yield could be improved by changing the polarity of the solvent. A DMF-EtOH (1:1) mixture was found to be a good solvent, leading to improved reaction yields (e.g., from 9.0 ± 3.2% in DMF at 100 °C for 10 min up to 63.2 ± 6.2% in DMF-EtOH at the same conditions). We showed that nucleation rate of MFU-4 could be greatly influenced by adding an alkali base which was responsible for ligand deprotonation. We also demonstrated that by changing the amount of added base, the crystal size could be finely tuned. Last but not least the usage of three simple amines (triethylamine, diethylamine, and n-hexylamine) as modulating ligands was studied. These act not only as competitive ligands in coordination equilibria but also as bases in deprotonation equilibria during nucleation and growth. Moreover, n-hexylamine was found to be a highly selective reagent, which changes the regular cubic crystal morphology of MFU-4 single crystals into an octahedral shape.

elements.content: To conclude, we developed several different synthesis procedures leading to uniform MFU-4 nanocrystals sufficiently small to be used as potential platforms for application in medicine. For instance, 104 ± 4 nm cubic nanocrystals with a narrow size distribution (PDI = 0.192) could be prepared in a DMF–EtOH (1:1) mixture in almost quantitative yield (97.4 ± 2.4) by microwave-assisted synthesis at 100 °C for 2 min. The novel synthesis strategies and insight into the nucleation process reported here may help to put size- and shape-controlled syntheses of nano- and microscale bulk MOF materials on a more rational basis. Indeed, the synthesis principles reported here may be transferable to other triazolate-based MOFs and possibly to other N-donor ligand based MOF systems (e.g., pyrazole- or imidazole-based).

For instance, 104 ± 4 nm cubic nanocrystals with a narrow size distribution (PDI = 0.192) could be prepared in a DMF-EtOH (1:1) mixture in almost quantitative yield (97.4 ± 2.4) by microwave-assisted synthesis at 100 °C for 2 min. The novel synthesis strategies and insight into the nucleation process reported here may help to put size- and shape-controlled syntheses of nano- and microscale bulk MOF materials on a more rational basis. Indeed, the synthesis principles reported here may be transferable to other triazolate-based MOFs and possibly to other N-donor ligand based MOF systems (e.g., pyrazole- or imidazole-based).

A typical solvothermal synthesis was performed as follows: a solution of anhydrous zinc chloride (34 mg, 0.25 mmol) and 1H,5H-benzo­(1,2-d:4,5-d′)­bistriazole (H2-BBTA, 10 mg, 0.06 mmol) in 2 mL of DMF was prepared in a heating test tube and placed into a heating block at 40, 60, 70, 90, 110, and 140 °C for 24 h. The obtained precipitate was examined with an optical microscope and then recovered by centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 10 min. The obtained solid was washed three times with DMF and dried in air. The reaction yield was calculated. All reactions were performed thrice to calculate the average and standard deviation.

To conclude, we developed several different synthesis procedures leading to uniform MFU-4 nanocrystals sufficiently small to be used as potential platforms for application in medicine. For instance, 104 ± 4 nm cubic nanocrystals with a narrow size distribution (PDI = 0.192) could be prepared in a DMF–EtOH (1:1) mixture in almost quantitative yield (97.4 ± 2.4) by microwave-assisted synthesis at 100 °C for 2 min. The novel synthesis strategies and insight into the nucleation process reported here may help to put size- and shape-controlled syntheses of nano- and microscale bulk MOF materials on a more rational basis. Indeed, the synthesis principles reported here may be transferable to other triazolate-based MOFs and possibly to other N-donor ligand based MOF systems (e.g., pyrazole- or imidazole-based).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Solvothermal Synthesis of MFU-4

A typical solvothermal synthesis was performed as follows: a solution of anhydrous zinc chloride (34 mg, 0.25 mmol) and 1H,5H-benzo(1,2-d:4,5-d')bistriazole (H2-BBTA, 10 mg, 0.06 mmol) in 2 mL of DMF was prepared in a heating test tube and placed into a heating block at 40, 60, 70, 90, 110, and 140 °C for 24 h. The obtained precipitate was examined with an optical microscope and then recovered by centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 10 min. The obtained solid was washed three times with DMF and dried in air. The reaction yield was calculated. All reactions were performed thrice to calculate the average and standard deviation.

To conclude, we developed several different synthesis procedures leading to uniform MFU-4 nanocrystals sufficiently small to be used as potential platforms for application in medicine. For instance, 104 ± 4 nm cubic nanocrystals with a narrow size distribution (PDI = 0.192) could be prepared in a DMF-EtOH (1:1) mixture in almost quantitative yield (97.4 ± 2.4) by microwave-assisted synthesis at 100 °C for 2 min. The novel synthesis strategies and insight into the nucleation process reported here may help to put size- and shape-controlled syntheses of nano- and microscale bulk MOF materials on a more rational basis. Indeed, the synthesis principles reported here may be transferable to other triazolate-based MOFs and possibly to other N-donor ligand based MOF systems (e.g., pyrazole- or imidazole-based).
